title: Job Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 22.

questions.question: Who answered in Job Chapter 22?
questions.correctAnswer: Eliphaz the Temanite
questions.explanation: Eliphaz the Temanite is the one who answered in Job 22:1.

questions.question: According to Job 22:5, how are the wickedness and iniquities described?
questions.correctAnswer: Great and infinite
questions.explanation: Verse Job 22:5 says, 'Is not thy wickedness great? and thine iniquities infinite?'

questions.question: What has the person in Job 22:6 done to his brother?
questions.correctAnswer: Taken a pledge for nought
questions.explanation: Job 22:6 states that the person has taken a pledge from his brother for nought and stripped the naked of their clothing.

questions.question: According to Job 22:7, what was withheld from the weary and hungry?
questions.correctAnswer: Water and bread
questions.explanation: Job 22:7 says, 'Thou hast not given water to the weary to drink, and thou hast withholden bread from the hungry.'

questions.question: Who had the earth according to Job 22:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The mighty man
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states, 'But as for the mighty man, he had the earth; and the honourable man dwelt in it.'

questions.question: What is said about widows and fatherless in Job 22:9?
options: Widows sent away empty, arms of fatherless broken
questions.correctAnswer: Widows sent away empty, arms of fatherless broken
questions.explanation: Job 22:9 states, 'Thou hast sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 22:10 says that snares and sudden fear trouble the person addressed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 22:10 says, 'Therefore snares are round about thee, and sudden fear troubleth thee;' confirming that this is true.

questions.question: According to Job 22:12, where is God located?
questions.correctAnswer: In the height of heaven
questions.explanation: Job 22:12 states, 'Is not God in the height of heaven?'

questions.question: What does the person say about God's knowledge in Job 22:13?
options: How doth God know? can he judge through the dark cloud?
questions.correctAnswer: How doth God know? can he judge through the dark cloud?
questions.explanation: Job 22:13 records the question, 'And thou sayest, How doth God know? can he judge through the dark cloud?'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Job 22:15: 'Hast thou marked the old way which ______ men have trodden?'
questions.correctAnswer: wicked
questions.explanation: Job 22:15 says, 'Hast thou marked the old way which wicked men have trodden?'

questions.question: What did the wicked say to God according to Job 22:17?
questions.correctAnswer: Depart from us
questions.explanation: Job 22:17 states, 'Which said unto God, Depart from us: and what can the Almighty do for them?'

questions.question: According to Job 22:21, what should one do to receive good?
options: Acquaint thyself with God and be at peace
questions.correctAnswer: Acquaint thyself with God and be at peace
questions.explanation: Verse 21 says, 'Acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace: thereby good shall come unto thee.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 22:23 says if you return to the Almighty, you shall put away iniquity far from your tabernacles.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Job 22:23 confirms, 'If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up, thou shalt put away iniquity far from thy tabernacles.'

questions.question: What shall the Almighty be to you according to Job 22:25?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy defence
questions.explanation: Job 22:25 says, 'Yea, the Almighty shall be thy defence, and thou shalt have plenty of silver.'

questions.question: True or False: Job 22:28 says when you decree a thing, it shall not be established.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Job 22:28 says, 'Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established unto thee,' so the statement is false.

medium.title: Job Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with guilt over past injustices. Based on Job 22, what biblical truth would you share about repentance and restoration?
options: If you return to the Almighty, you will be built up and put away iniquity from your tabernacles.
God only accepts perfect righteousness and does not forgive.
You must earn God's favor by strict works without repentance.
Ignoring sin will cause God to bless you anyway.
questions.correctAnswer: If you return to the Almighty, you will be built up and put away iniquity from your tabernacles.
questions.explanation: Job 22:23 teaches that returning to God leads to restoration and removal of sin. Verses 21-25 encourage seeking God, receiving His law, and experiencing peace and blessing through obedience.

questions.question: How does Job 22 teach about humility in the face of trials?
options: The humble will be saved and lifted up by God.
Pride is rewarded by God with prosperity.
Trials indicate God’s rejection without hope.
One should rely on their own strength alone.
questions.correctAnswer: The humble will be saved and lifted up by God.
questions.explanation: Verse 29 promises that God saves the humble. This shows humility is valued and leads to deliverance even amid trials (Job 22:29; also see verses 21 and 27).

questions.question: What does Job 22 say about generosity towards those in need?
options: Withholding bread from the hungry and water from the weary is condemned.
It is acceptable to ignore the needs of others.
Wealth should be kept for oneself alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Withholding bread from the hungry and water from the weary is condemned.
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 and 9 rebuke taking advantage of others and neglecting widows and orphans. This teaches the virtue of generosity and care for the vulnerable.

questions.question: A believer feels distant from God and questions if He sees their struggles. How does Job 22 address God's awareness?
options: God is in the height of heaven and sees all, even through clouds and darkness.
God does not see through darkness or hidden places.
God only judges the righteous, ignoring the wicked.
God is unaware of human suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: God is in the height of heaven and sees all, even through clouds and darkness.
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 affirm God's exalted position and that clouds do not hide Him. He walks the heavens and judges all.

questions.question: According to Job 22, what is a practical step to attain peace and good in life?
options: Acquaint yourself with God and be at peace.
Rely on your own wisdom instead of God.
Avoid God's law to live freely.
questions.correctAnswer: Acquaint yourself with God and be at peace.
questions.explanation: Verse 21 explicitly instructs to become familiar with God to receive peace and good. This is a practical call to relationship and trust.

questions.question: How does Job 22 emphasize the importance of prayer and vows?
options: Prayers will be heard and vows fulfilled when made to God.
Prayer is unnecessary if you are righteous.
Vows to God are optional and unimportant.
God does not respond to human prayers.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayers will be heard and vows fulfilled when made to God.
questions.explanation: Verse 27 promises God will hear prayers and that vows will be paid. This highlights the value of sincere communication with God.

questions.question: What does Job 22 imply about the consequences of wickedness?
options: Snares, sudden fear, and darkness come upon the wicked.
Wickedness leads to eternal peace without trouble.
The wicked are always honored and prosper.
questions.correctAnswer: Snares, sudden fear, and darkness come upon the wicked.
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 describe snares and fear troubling the wicked, indicating consequences of sin.

questions.question: What does Job 22 teach about integrity in financial and social dealings?
options: Taking pledges without cause and stripping the naked is condemned.
It is acceptable to exploit others financially.
Integrity is irrelevant to God’s judgment.
Only outward appearances matter, not actions.
questions.correctAnswer: Taking pledges without cause and stripping the naked is condemned.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 rebukes taking unfair pledges and exploiting the poor, teaching honesty and justice in dealings.

questions.question: True or False: Job 22 states that God's counsel is close to the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 18 explicitly says the counsel of the wicked is far from the speaker, indicating distance from God’s wisdom.

questions.question: True or False: Job 22 encourages believers to lay up God's words in their hearts.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 22 urges receiving the law from God's mouth and storing His words in the heart, emphasizing obedience and devotion.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Job 22, if you return to the Almighty, you shall lay up gold as ______, and the gold of Ophir as the stones of the brooks.
questions.correctAnswer: dust
questions.explanation: Verse 24 states that gold will be laid up as dust, symbolizing abundant blessing upon reconciliation with God.

questions.question: How does Job 22 describe the attitude of the innocent toward the wicked?
options: The innocent laugh them to scorn and are glad at their downfall.
The innocent sympathize with the wicked.
The innocent ignore the wicked's fate.
The innocent join in the wicked’s counsel.
questions.correctAnswer: The innocent laugh them to scorn and are glad at their downfall.
questions.explanation: Verse 19 explains that the innocent mock the wicked and rejoice over their consequences, highlighting justice and discernment.

questions.question: What practical advice does Job 22 offer for dealing with despair and fear?
options: Trust in God and decree a thing, and it will be established with light shining on your ways.
Give in to despair and lose hope.
Avoid God and rely on human strength.
Fear is permanent and cannot be overcome.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God and decree a thing, and it will be established with light shining on your ways.
questions.explanation: Verse 28 encourages confident prayer and trust in God’s establishment of one’s plans, bringing light to one’s path.

questions.question: What does Job 22 teach about God’s defense and provision for those who obey Him?
options: The Almighty shall be your defense and you shall have plenty of silver.
God abandons those who obey Him.
Obedience leads to poverty and weakness.
Defense and provision come only from human effort.
questions.correctAnswer: The Almighty shall be your defense and you shall have plenty of silver.
questions.explanation: Verse 25 promises God's protection and material blessing for the obedient, emphasizing divine provision and care.

questions.question: How does Job 22 address the theme of justice for the fatherless and widows?
options: Sending widows away empty and breaking the arms of orphans is condemned.
Widows and orphans should fend for themselves.
Justice for widows and orphans is unimportant.
questions.correctAnswer: Sending widows away empty and breaking the arms of orphans is condemned.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 condemns neglect and injustice to vulnerable groups, teaching responsibility to care for them.

hard.title: Job Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 22.

questions.question: In Job 22:5-9, Eliphaz accuses Job of several social injustices. Which of the following is NOT one of the accusations mentioned?
options: Taking a pledge from a brother for nought
Stripping the naked of their clothing
questions.correctAnswer: Building altars to false gods
questions.explanation: Eliphaz accuses Job of social wrongs such as taking pledges unfairly, stripping the naked, withholding water and bread, and mistreating widows and orphans (Job 22:6-9). There is no mention of building altars to false gods.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Eliphaz ask in Job 22:3 to challenge Job's belief in his own righteousness?
options: Is it any pleasure to the Almighty, that thou art righteous?
Can a man be profitable unto God?
Will God enter into judgment with thee?
questions.correctAnswer: Is it any pleasure to the Almighty, that thou art righteous?
questions.explanation: Eliphaz challenges Job's claim to righteousness by asking if God takes pleasure in human righteousness or gains from perfect ways (Job 22:3).

questions.question: Eliphaz in Job 22:12-14 uses imagery of the heavens and clouds. What is the main point he is making with this imagery?
options: That God's knowledge is hidden behind clouds and darkness
That God is distant and does not see human actions
That God is in the height of heaven and sees all despite the clouds
That the stars control human fate
questions.correctAnswer: That God is in the height of heaven and sees all despite the clouds
questions.explanation: Eliphaz notes that though clouds may cover God, He sees all from heaven and walks in the circuit of the heavens, implying God's omniscience (Job 22:12-14).

questions.question: In Job 22:15-17, Eliphaz refers to 'the old way which wicked men have trodden.' What historical or theological theme is he alluding to?
options: The Flood and judgment on the ungodly
questions.correctAnswer: The Flood and judgment on the ungodly
questions.explanation: Eliphaz refers to those cut down 'out of time' whose foundations were overflown by a flood and who rejected God, alluding to the Flood narrative (Job 22:16-17).

questions.question: How does Eliphaz describe the counsel of the wicked in Job 22:18-19?
options: It is full of wisdom and strength
questions.correctAnswer: It is far from Eliphaz
questions.explanation: Eliphaz states that the counsel of the wicked is far from him, indicating his rejection of wicked advice (Job 22:18).

questions.question: What does Eliphaz urge Job to do in order to receive peace and good (Job 22:21-23)?
options: Acquaint himself with God and return to the Almighty
Seek riches and honor in this life
Leave his land and start anew
questions.correctAnswer: Acquaint himself with God and return to the Almighty
questions.explanation: Eliphaz advises Job to get close to God, receive His law, and return to Him to be built up and have iniquity removed (Job 22:21-23).

questions.question: The promise that 'thou shalt lay up gold as dust' and 'the gold of Ophir as the stones of the brooks' (Job 22:24) is an example of what literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The comparison 'as dust' and 'as the stones of the brooks' uses similes to emphasize abundance (Job 22:24).

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say will be the result when Job 'shall make thy prayer unto him' (Job 22:27)?
options: God shall hear thee and thou shalt pay thy vows
Thou shalt be wealthy beyond measure
questions.correctAnswer: God shall hear thee and thou shalt pay thy vows
questions.explanation: Eliphaz promises that if Job prays to God, God will hear him and Job will fulfill his vows (Job 22:27).

questions.question: According to Job 22:28, what is the significance of decreeing a thing?
options: It will be established unto thee
It will be questioned by others
questions.correctAnswer: It will be established unto thee
questions.explanation: Eliphaz states that when one decrees a thing, it shall be established and light will shine on their ways (Job 22:28).

questions.question: In Job 22:29-30, Eliphaz speaks of lifting up the humble and delivering the innocent. Which New Testament theme does this foreshadow?
options: Jesus as the Savior who lifts the humble
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus as the Savior who lifts the humble
questions.explanation: The promise of lifting up the humble and delivering the innocent foreshadows New Testament themes of Jesus uplifting the lowly and innocent (Job 22:29-30).

questions.question: How does Eliphaz characterize God's defense and provision for the righteous in Job 22:25?
options: As a mighty fortress and overflowing harvest
As a defense and plenty of silver
questions.correctAnswer: As a defense and plenty of silver
questions.explanation: Eliphaz says that the Almighty shall be Job's defense and he will have abundance of silver (Job 22:25).

questions.question: True or False: In Job 22:10-11, Eliphaz describes sudden fear and darkness as consequences surrounding Job due to his sins.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Eliphaz warns that snares, sudden fear, darkness, and overwhelming waters trouble Job as consequences of his wrongdoing (Job 22:10-11).

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of Eliphaz's reference to 'the gold of Ophir' in Job 22:24?
options: It represents great wealth and prosperity
It is a metaphor for wisdom
It is a reference to a foreign god
questions.correctAnswer: It represents great wealth and prosperity
questions.explanation: Ophir was famous in the ancient Near East for its fine gold, symbolizing great wealth (Job 22:24).

questions.question: Eliphaz questions Job’s understanding of God's judgment in Job 22:13. What does this reveal about Eliphaz's theological perspective?
options: He doubts God’s ability to judge
He believes God is just and fully aware of human actions
He views God as punishing without cause
questions.correctAnswer: He believes God is just and fully aware of human actions
questions.explanation: Eliphaz questions Job’s skepticism about God’s judgment but affirms God’s omniscience and justice despite the 'dark cloud' (Job 22:13).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the remnant of them the fire consumeth' in Job 22:20 in the context of Near Eastern imagery?
options: It signifies purification and judgment by fire
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies purification and judgment by fire
questions.explanation: Fire in ancient Near Eastern contexts often symbolizes divine judgment and purification, as Eliphaz uses here to describe the fate of the wicked (Job 22:20).

theological.title: Job Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz in Job 22, what is the nature of a man's righteousness before God?
options: It brings Him no pleasure or gain
God reprove men for being righteous
questions.correctAnswer: It brings Him no pleasure or gain
questions.explanation: Eliphaz states in Job 22:3 that it is not any pleasure to the Almighty that a man is righteous or gain to Him that he makes his ways perfect, indicating God's righteousness standard is not about human merit. This aligns with Isaiah 64:6 and Romans 3:10-12, showing all have sinned and none are righteous by their works.

questions.question: What accusations does Eliphaz make against Job in Job 22?
options: He has taken pledges from his brother for nothing and stripped the naked
He has been generous to the poor and widows
He has been righteous and just
questions.correctAnswer: He has taken pledges from his brother for nothing and stripped the naked
questions.explanation: In Job 22:6-7, Eliphaz accuses Job of taking pledges from his brother for nothing and not helping the weary or hungry, highlighting Job's alleged social injustices. This reflects the biblical principle in Proverbs 22:22-23 and Isaiah 1:17 condemning exploitation and neglect of the needy.

questions.question: What consequences does Eliphaz say surround Job due to his actions?
options: Snares and sudden fear trouble him
He is surrounded by peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Snares and sudden fear trouble him
questions.explanation: Job 22:10 describes that snares are around Job and sudden fear troubles him as a result of his wickedness. This fits the biblical theme of sin's consequences seen in Psalms 91:3 and Proverbs 1:26-27, where wickedness leads to danger and fear.

questions.question: How does Eliphaz describe God's knowledge and visibility according to Job 22?
options: God is in the height of heaven and sees through thick clouds
God is limited by human understanding
God judges only in clear daylight
questions.correctAnswer: God is in the height of heaven and sees through thick clouds
questions.explanation: In Job 22:12-14, Eliphaz explains that God is exalted in heaven and walks in the circuit of heaven, seeing through thick clouds, illustrating God's omniscience and omnipresence consistent with Psalms 139:7-12 and Daniel 4:35.

questions.question: What is the attitude of the wicked men Eliphaz refers to in Job 22:17?
options: They say to God, 'Depart from us'
questions.correctAnswer: They say to God, 'Depart from us'
questions.explanation: Job 22:17 states wicked men say to God, 'Depart from us,' showing their rebellion and rejection of divine authority, paralleling Proverbs 1:24-28 and Isaiah 65:12 where the wicked reject God's call and face judgment.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say will happen if Job returns to the Almighty?
options: He shall be built up and put away iniquity far from his tabernacles
He will be abandoned by God
His wealth will be taken away
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be built up and put away iniquity far from his tabernacles
questions.explanation: Job 22:23 explains that upon returning to God, Job will be restored and cleanse his dwelling from sin, reflecting biblical themes of repentance leading to restoration found in 2 Chronicles 7:14 and Isaiah 1:16-18.

questions.question: What blessings does Eliphaz promise will come to Job if he obeys God?
options: Gold as dust, plenty of silver, and God's defense
questions.correctAnswer: Gold as dust, plenty of silver, and God's defense
questions.explanation: In Job 22:24-25, Eliphaz promises abundant wealth and God's protection if Job submits to God, consistent with Deuteronomy 28:1-14 and Psalm 112:3 which connect obedience with divine blessing.

questions.question: What is the result of delighting in the Almighty according to Job 22?
options: Lifting up of one's face to God and answered prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Lifting up of one's face to God and answered prayer
questions.explanation: Job 22:26-27 promises that delighting in God leads to confidence before Him and that prayers will be heard, paralleling Psalm 34:15-18 and Jeremiah 29:12-13 about God's attentiveness to those who seek Him.

questions.question: According to Eliphaz, what will happen when Job decrees a thing?
options: It shall be established unto him and light shall shine upon his ways
It will be ignored by God
It will be challenged by others
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be established unto him and light shall shine upon his ways
questions.explanation: Job 22:28 teaches that decrees made in alignment with God will be established and illuminated, echoing Matthew 16:19 and Psalm 119:105 about God's guidance and authority given to the faithful.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say will happen to the humble person according to Job 22:29?
options: He shall be saved and lifted up
He will be cast down again
He will be ignored by God
questions.correctAnswer: He shall be saved and lifted up
questions.explanation: Job 22:29 states that the humble will be saved and lifted up, consistent with James 4:6 and 1 Peter 5:5 which affirm God exalts the humble and opposes the proud.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz mean by 'the island of the innocent' in Job 22:30?
options: A place delivered by the pureness of one's hands
A literal island inhabited by saints
questions.correctAnswer: A place delivered by the pureness of one's hands
questions.explanation: Job 22:30 uses 'island of the innocent' metaphorically to represent a place of deliverance secured by purity and righteousness, paralleling Isaiah 1:16-17 and Matthew 5:8 emphasizing holiness and justice as means of salvation.

questions.question: How does Eliphaz describe the foundation of the wicked men who were cut down in Job 22?
options: Their foundation was overflown with a flood
Their foundation was built on rock
Their foundation was strong and secure
questions.correctAnswer: Their foundation was overflown with a flood
questions.explanation: Job 22:16 states the foundation of wicked men was overflown with a flood, symbolizing instability and destruction, aligning with Matthew 7:26-27 where a house built on sand collapses.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say about the counsel of the wicked in Job 22:18?
options: It is accepted by the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: It is far from him
questions.explanation: In Job 22:18 Eliphaz declares the counsel of the wicked is far from him, implying separation from evil advice. This matches Proverbs 4:14-15 and Psalm 1:1 where the righteous avoid the way of sinners.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz say the righteous do when they see the fate of the wicked?
options: They are glad and the innocent laugh them to scorn
questions.correctAnswer: They are glad and the innocent laugh them to scorn
questions.explanation: Job 22:19 shows the righteous rejoice at seeing the wicked judged, reflecting Psalm 37:1-2 and Proverbs 24:17 which affirm the joy of the godly when wickedness is punished.

questions.question: What does Eliphaz imply about God's judgment in relation to human sinfulness in Job 22?
options: God judges because of great wickedness and infinite iniquities
God only judges those who are unrighteous
questions.correctAnswer: God judges because of great wickedness and infinite iniquities
questions.explanation: Job 22:5 states that man's wickedness is great and iniquities are infinite, justifying God's judgment, consistent with Romans 3:23 and Hebrews 9:27 emphasizing universal sinfulness and divine judgment.
